data.text: .@g20org calls for more contributions from countries to scale up the lending capacity of the IMF’s Poverty Reduction and Growth Trust and provide debt service relief through the Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust. https://t.co/DcVdNafsXW https://t.co/JJOeM7lkXw

.@KGeorgieva said low vaccines access and limited policy space are holding back the recovery in many EMs and developing economies. “Helping them is morally right, and in our own interest everywhere.” https://t.co/3jOmZKqUGD #IMFMeetings https://t.co/aw1ML9L06X

Headline inflation in advanced economy group is forecast to peak in the coming months, declining to 2% on average in 2022, amidst economic uncertainty. More in our latest #WEO research: https://t.co/b47dDvAuYk https://t.co/zhkL1KTQ0l

.@KGeorgieva: IMF climate priorities - cover #mitigation issues for largest emitters and #adaptation for vulnerable countries. Make the Resilience & Sustainability Trust a reality. Work with MDBs to amplify the impact of policies & financing. https://t.co/RoBP5msyat https://t.co/zgQxGHkh1t

The @g20org calls on the IMF to create a Resilience and Sustainability Trust to help low-income and vulnerable countries build resilience and transform their economies. 
https://t.co/1I6QBFcXaz https://t.co/2uGdTzas7b

.@KGeorgieva: persistent divergence between advanced and emerging countries risks a disruption of supply chains and may contribute to inflation. What can be done?

The IMF projects the global economy to grow at 5.9% in 2021 and 4.9% in 2022, 0.1 percentage points lower for 2021 than the July forecast. 

More in the latest World Economic Outlook ➡️ https://t.co/j0FIiCIKcQ #WEO https://t.co/sOvFKyLJHV

Vaccine access, supply disruptions, and early policy support are widening gaps in recoveries across economies. Here are the IMF’s latest growth projections by region. https://t.co/hYpP2Ag5d6 #WEO https://t.co/ChIgv5rZi7

Global public debt now amounts to nearly 100% of GDP. Countries will need to calibrate fiscal policies to their own unique circumstances,  including the rate of vaccination and strength of the recovery. Learn more on #IMFBlog

The room for countries to increase spending is becoming more limited. However, countries should continue to prioritize healthcare spending, provide lifelines to weak households and firms, and fund retraining and support for reallocation. https://t.co/oIzPyG8yYI #WEO #IMFBlog https://t.co/kvRteLWent

We forecast growth for emerging market and developing economies at 6.4% in 2021, a marginal revision from our July forecast. Growth will moderate to 5.1% in 2022. Read the latest World Economic Outlook to learn more: https://t.co/hYpP2Ag5d6 #WEO. https://t.co/DkolCT2wNy

This is a time for far-sighted policies that must be carefully crafted, aiming to avoid unintended consequences that could put growth at risk and lead to an abrupt adjustment in the financial market. https://t.co/c2FRKBCbHy #GFSR https://t.co/2S171TLjax

Global GDP could be reduced by a cumulative $5.3 trillion over the next 5 years if the impact of the pandemic prolongs. @GitaGopinath writes that we need to step up efforts to ensure #vaccinequity for every country and overcome vaccine hesitancy. https://t.co/oIzPyGqani #WEO https://t.co/9eRgNprIVu

Today in our #IMFmeetings recap, we take stock of the economic forecast for the world. We discuss the risks to global financial stability, and examine how we can support a recovery that benefits all. #WEO #GFSR #InclusiveRecovery

Policymakers are confronted with a difficult tradeoff: they must continue to provide support now to the global economy and simultaneously avoid the build-up of financial stability risks over the next few years. https://t.co/c2FRKBTMz6 #GFSR https://t.co/EGHZKVjxtM

Financial stability risks have been contained so far. But investors are increasingly worried about the economic outlook amid uncertainties that could lead to higher interest rates. https://t.co/c2FRKBCbHy #GFSR https://t.co/nLuDymlXsU

Low interest rates during the pandemic have allowed for high asset valuations to persist. If this continues, financial vulnerabilities could intensify. Read our latest #IMFBlog for the full analysis: https://t.co/mSSFcQLCNf #GFSR https://t.co/RUSJHIuk97

Spain🇪🇸: 6.4%

India🇮🇳: 8.5%

Mexico🇲🇽: 4%
KSA🇸🇦: 4.8%

S. Africa🇿🇦: 2.2%
